review_body: The hotel location is great, with only few minutes walk from the subway. An array of convenient restaurants in the proximity of the hotel. Although the rooms are small, it provide a good comfort. Nevertheless, the receptionist upon arrival was holding our passports for about 10 minutes.The other 2 receptionists next to her started to laugh loudly. Once the check in has been made, no explanation about the hotel facilities, nether to explain us which floor was located the room making us feel very unwelcome. We have used previously same hotel brand at Kyoto and our experience with them was enjoyable. In the evening, I have called the reception and asked for an extra duvet with the beed sheet as we were 3 people. However, the answer was “we don’t have any extra duvet”. Clearly there is a lack of training or not respect for the foreigners?

the room was a normal size for Tokyo, clean, quiet, all in all nice, would have appreciated to have also English instructions for airconditioning and in the bathroom. Breakfast was buffet style, nothing spectacular but good

The rooms are very compact, as usual in Tokyo. There was not a lot of room once we brought our bags in but it was fine. The hotel is professional and clean, the staff are helpful and keen to help and the bed was comfy - although I do recommend getting another soft pillow from reception as they give one super hard pillow and one soft, which flattens. The bath was short but nice and deep. There is an elevator right to the 7/11 downstairs which is super helpful as you can get everything from 7/11 - I will miss them back in Australia, we don't carry nearly the same range! The only improvement that I would suggest to the hotel is to add on some cable channels on the tv for free so that international guests can watch something other than the few local japanese channels. Overall - I'd stay again!

Our family of 4 spent 3 nights at this hotel in a twin room. It was cozy, functional with all amenities we needed. They even supply charging cables for all our various electronics devices. The hotel also has DIY laundry facilities which is free for guest to use. We didn’t eat at the hotel but 7 11 is downstairs and they stock basically everything we needed first thing in the morning or at the end of our day from sightseeing. Akasaka itself is a lovely and relatively quiet area which we appreciated after the hustle and bustle of Shinjuku or Shibuya. The nearest metro is 3min walk away and being Tokyo there are plenty of places to eat around the hotel.

Small rooms (standard in Tokyo) but in any case bigger than other place I visited. High level of services and amenities in the room. Metro is 3 minutes walk distance. Cleanlinsess level is goos. I raccomand this hotel.

This hotel is located only 5 mins walk to the station with bars, supermarkets and restaurants around. Also, there is a medium sized shrine within 8 mins walk. The room is small but clean with nice toiletries. However, the only downside is that the aircon seems to be pretty noisy which is quite disturbing. Overall, it’s a pleasant stay, great for business trip.

I am happy with the room and internet. The breakfast is cash only and a moderate selection. There are coffee shops a few blocks to the north. There is an English pub northeast for good beers. Authentic burger is close by (cash only). There is an ATM at the MUFG bank in the basement of the ATT New Tower that is relatively close to the southeast.Using the Limousine bus stop at the Intercontinental ANA is pretty convenient to get to and from Narita. It's 10 minutes away at the most.I don't use the trains much, but there are stations nearby.

The double bedroom was small, clean and comfortable. Bathroom was clean with good quality toiletries. The electric bidet toilet was a plus. The provision of a handheld gps device offered daily weather info and navigation assistance. We appreciated the laundry room for our week's stay as well as the complimentary storage of luggage. The hotel is well located, close to restaurants and near to two subway stations. Pleased overall with the week's accommodation. Recommended to business travellers and visitors.

Tokyo is expensive. The hotel was reasonably priced. Excellent location. Within walking distance of a large number of excellent restaurants, two metro stops and several stores where you can purchase supermarket type items including pre-packaged meals. The rooms are small by American standards but well designed. There is a restaurant in the hotel and a 7-Eleven store directly under the hotel (important because 7-Eleven stores have ATM machines that exchange currency). Moreover, the hotel has an excellent front-desk staff. I had the opportunity to communicate by email with the staff before arriving. Replies were always prompt, responsive and informative. After arriving, staff was always very helpful-providing information about Tokyo attractions, restaurants and travel in and outside the city. The hotel has an interesting policy of providing cell phones in the room for guest use. This came in handy because I had to get in contact with the airlines the day before my departure. I was able to make a local call using the cell phone without incurring the expenses of an international call on my phone. Pajamas are also provided.The morning of our departure, Tony, one of the English speaking desk managers, called us a cab, provided us with instructions on how to take the mono-rail to the airport, gave the cab driver instructions on where to take us, walked us to the cab and bade us adieu. An excellent way to end our stay in Tokyo.I give this hotel a 4.5 rating only because of the size of the room and no business center. Otherwise, I would give it a 5 for location, service and cleanliness. i recommend this hotel and would stay again.

the location was perfect, the area was safe, clean and had all the necessary stores around. the public areas very clean and the staff very helpful. there is a robot in the reception, so cute! the room although it is small, it was very comfortable that we didn't even notice the lack of space! many amenities in the bathroom and room. the breakfast has a big variety of asian food and a small in European, i may sat that we didn't enjoy it and had trouble in eating good. overall experience, very good, we will be back (but not take the breakfast!).

This hotel is located in between Roppongi and Akasaka. There are at least 2 subway stations nearby (both stations are about 5 minutes walk from the hotel) so the location is great. The room is just a typical Japanese business hotel type, small but clean and comfortable. There’s a convenience store in the basement which was great.

Excellent location! Really nice area, considering the craziness of the streets of Tokyo, this was a more relaxing, quiet area which was nice to escape to. It’s near three subway lines, all within short walking distances. The rooms were fairly big for what you may expect in Japan and had good facilities - exactly what you need for a city break! My only issue was the customer service at reception, they were not helpful at all. When we checked in, they failed to give us any information, even to tell us that there was a phone we could use with free WiFi, which we only discovered after a day (when we had already bought a sim). If we asked them a question, we almost felt stupid asking them due to their response! They’re english was good, so that wasn’t the reason - I just found them to be a little rude.

The hotel is just few minutes from Akasaka station, and about 15-20 minutes from Roppongi. The hotel seems new, modern, very clean, but with small rooms. Free internet, which works very well. very friendly personnel too.

Stayed 2 nights, with spouse and 2 children. Two twin beds, a little tight sleeping wise. Room wasn't too small. Nice bathroom, separate toilet. Free phone for use during stay with some international calling included. Breakfast was quite good. Staff at the front desk were very helpful. I think we paid about Yen 20,000 nightly including the breakfast. I would stay again.

Nothing to complain about really at all. A great hotel with warm service. Breakfast was expensive and limited for vegetarians but we had to have it one day as the rain was torrential. Not the best neighbourhood for a first visit to Tokyo in terms of restaurants close by but we managed. The metro was an easy stroll. For five stars it would have been nice to be able to check in and freshen up after arriving mid-morning from a long-haul flight - otherwise good!

I stayed about one week in japan. Mystays akasaka was the first hotel to stay in Tokyo. However, the staff and receptionest were very helpfull and polite. I stayed two days in kyoto and I return to tokyo to the same hotel because I know I will have a very pleasant stay with them. I hope come back again.
user_name:
Abu_Dhabi_2015
Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

review_body: The hotel was better then what i had anticipated, its a no frills hotel in a excellent location small rooms like most hotels in Tokyo but surprisingly good sized bathroom,The rooms had everything in it and extremely clean, the location is fantastic The hotel has a 24/7 grocery shop in the same building 7/11 which is excellent.For the price i would stay here again for sure .

We stayed here 3 nights. It is a perfect base to see all the sights of Tokyo. The hotel is about a 4 minute walk from the Akasaka subway station. There are many restaurants and bars within a 5-10 minute walk. The rooms are a decent size, clean and comfortable. The staff is friendly, and very helpful with any arrangements you need.

We enjoy visiting Tokyo at least once a year. This year we tried MyStays in Akasaka as our usual b-Hotel was fully booked. Our Friend has just recommended it as well.Hotel was clean and well cared for. It is a short walk from several station. and lots of restaurant nearby especially beyond the Akasaka station like Midori no Suahi. Also great Thai massage place nearby (Erawan) with email reservation.The hotel embodies the omotenashi spiritand anticipated a foreigner’s need like -1. Mobile phone free of charge for using maps and even local/international calling.2. Washing machine and dryer3. Near airport limousine drop off and pick up point - Ana Intercontinental. 4. Excellent shower facility5. Breakfast - Asian or Weatern6. 7-11 convenience store at basement 7. Potable water from the TOP8. Shampoo, conditioner, body soap and implement and hair dryer9. Card activated elevator for security10. Lots of room choiceLooking forward to return.

My Husband and I stayed at this hotel for 9 nights, using it as a base to explore Tokyo. It is about a 3 minute walk from Akasaka subway station so excellent transport links. The area was very quiet with quite a business vibe. Check in was quick and Pepper the concierge robot was a great novelty. Room was on the tenth floor with nice views. Typical of Japan and the price level, the hotel room was quite small, as we both had large suitcases we didn't have any room to both unpack. Bed was very comfortable, shower warm and powerful. We heard no noise from.any other rooms. We ate breakfast in hotel once, it was buffet style and not much to write home about. We didn't eat dinner. There's a Gyoza restaurant next to the station which was amazing, and a McDonald's which was handy for breakfast. Overall I would recommend this hotel for both business and tourism.

Stayed here for 4 days, this property is verrry clean and quiet, staff are very professional and helpful, we found the room small for 2 people with 4 suitcases as there is not much storage room, the bed was hard and the foam pillows left us with sore necks in the morning, there are many restaurants close by as well as the subway, the breakfast in the morning had a good selection, for the price it was a good deal, next time I would get the larger room.

While this hotel is not in the middle of a super-busy area it gives you some feeling of privacy with good access to almost everywhere you want to go. It is a few minutes walk to Akasaka subway station and within walking distance to Roppongi. It’s easy to get from here to Shibuya, Omote-sando and Shinjuku too. Usually I warn people away from non-completely central locations if it’s their first time to Tokyo. Here I would say the exact opposite: if you’re new to Tokyo stay here by all means!Rooms are fine, not luxurious but reasonable size by Japanese standards and WiFi was good.Staff here was extraordinarily helpful and even helped me ship a bag I didn’t need to my next location before I’d checked in!

We stayed at this hotel in Tokyo for 3 nights late last month. It is a relatively new hotel; it opened only 2 years ago.My husband and I booked a Superior Queen room (17 sqm) and our two adult children occupied a Superior Twin room (23 sqm). We liked how quiet it was, both inside and outside the hotel.Our rooms were cleaned everyday impeccably. There was cable TV but we got only 1 that was in English, viz. CNN. We appreciated the super-comfortable beds and the memory-foam head pillows. There was no shortage of electrical outlets, and there was even a USB outlet in the headboard.The hotel is about 5 minutes walk from Akasaka Station. It is a longer walk to Tameike-Sanno station (about 10 minutes), which is where we usually took the trains to Ginza and Tsukiji market. There are a number of restaurants very close to the hotel, but we didn't try any of them. We also did not eat at the hotel food outlets, so I am unable to comment about them.I am very grateful to the staff at the front desk for helping us weigh our luggage and for holding the bags for us after we checked out and went for lunch. I worried that they wouldn't understand me when I asked to borrow a weighing scale. It took a couple of minutes for them to figure out what I needed. All's well that ends well.There was a robot named Pepper at the lobby to answer questions from guests. This is Japan!I will not hesitate to return to this hotel next time.

The stay was very good in this hotel. It is very central and hast good metro connections. The rooms are very small for two persons with luggage. But nevertheless, I would go again. Staff is very friendly and helpfull.

We chose this hotel based on the reviews on this site and the hotel lived up to the hype. Here's why I give it the trifecta:1- Location: it's so quiet and peaceful here, a nice break from the hustle and bustle of shinjuku and Shibuya. A short 5 minute walk to the subway. Tons of very good restaurants within walking distance with the 7 eleven downstairs for snacks and light meals.2- Room: We chose the superior queen and it was fine even though it was small...think of it like a room on a cruise ship. It was super functional and immaculate. No nOise from any of the other rooms and the water pressure in the shower was impressive. Nice to have at least CNN to keep up with the news, all other channels were in Japanese. Hotel provided a 4G cell phone which eliminated costly roaming charges and provided access to the Internet anywhere we went which was a lifesaver. You absolutely need google maps to find your way around the city and the subway system.3- Staff: The staff here is top notch . They never say no, always do things with a smile and in the most respectful manner. Checkin was supper quick and anytime we had to go to to reception for anything there was never any wait time. Pepper, the robot in the lobby was a hoot.I would have no problem staying here on my next trip to Tokyo, and have no issue recommending this hotel at any price point.

We appreciated the clean well designed room with USB outlets and multiple types of chargers. The Handy with WiFi capacity for maps and emails was useful. The bathroom and amenities were excellent! Staff were very helpful and arranged for our luggage to be transferred to our Osaka hotel seamlessly. We loved the location- local supermarkets and restaurants and a good vibe. Good access to metro stations.

Good location in the city, had several restaurants and tourist spots plus shops within walking distance. Prices are affordable and service is good.The rooms are a bit small, but we expected it because that is the usual situation in Japan.

This hotel is close to several metro stations, in a lively area full of nice restaurants and yet very quiet. It is well equipped and pleasant, for an eminently reasonable price. I will most likely come back on my next trip to Tokyo.

Location of the hotel is very good - close to the subway station but relatively quiet compared to other Tokyo neighbourhoods we have seen. Staff helpful. Room small (which is normal in Japan) but very clean. Available mobile device very helpful to navigate around Tokyo free of charge. Laundry machines working well

It was my first time traveling to Tokyo and and I wanted to do it right. Among researching about things to do and places to eat, I did a lot of research on hotels. I chose this hotel because of the location, price and great reviews. Minato is the opposite of the crazy busy ShinjukuI. It's a quite neighborhood that i could totally see myself live in with tons of restaurants and bars. It's a good breather after a full day of tourist attractions. Akasaka station is a short 5 mins walk (tip, take exit 5b). I stayed in a double bed. Yes it's the standard small room but it fit both my 28" luggage and my friend's 24" luggage comfortably. This hotel and most Japanese hotels provides all the amenities you will ever need. Gosh, I really love that about Japan. And don't get me started with their bidets. Best invention ever. haha. Full size shampoo, conditioner and body wash is available and very good quality may I add. Not like the cheap, tiny bottles that totally dry out your hair. We had a courtesy phone to use while in Tokyo and also a usb multi charging cable for about any type of phone, camera, or tablet. Both ends of the bed had a usb and outlet so let's just say we never had to fight over who can charge our phones. The hotel is so clean and modern. The staff were super helpful and spoke good english. There seems to be a shortage of irons because it was not available when i first asked but i was able to get one the very next day. We used the coin operated laundry facility early morning. English translation was provided which was helpful. Tokyo was the beginning of our 2 week trip and the hotel gladly stored our large luggage while we traveled to other cities for a week. I just can't think of anything this hotel did not have. Oh a plus, there's a 7-11 right next door! A perfect place to grab a onigiri, drink or michelin star package ramen!

There is no doubt that the rooms are small, but they are designed well and everything has its purpose. The hotel is in a quiet neighborhood, less than five minutes walk from the Akasaka metro station, with many small restaurants and bars in the neighborhood. The hotel staff is friendly and very accommodating.

Hotel Mystays was located in a great central area, with easy access to different rail lines to cover all the directions you would need to go. My room was great (#318) all the needs and more covered, no issue for 1 person. The reception staff were extremely helpful with suggestions on eating locations and printing off tickets. The hotel is very modern and stylish and I am happy to return here in the future and to recommend it to others.

I recommend staying here. My husband and I stayed here for 4 nights while in Tokyo. Having never been before it was hard to decide what neighborhood to stay in, etc., but this was a great choice! It is a few minutes walk from the Chiyoda Metro line ("C06 Akasaka" stop), which was convenient - the neighborhood is easy to get to and easy to travel from. There is a 7-11 in the basement/first floor of the hotel - good for ATM, snacks, etc., plenty of restaurants within walking distance. The hotel has a restaurant as well - we never went, but only because we felt like exploring, but the prices and menu looked fine and reasonable. The hotel itself is immaculate, quiet, private, well stocked of all the supplies you'd need or expect (shampoo, etc.), and very comfortable.If it's helpful, upon arrival, we took a limousine bus (no reservations necessary) from the Narita airport to a hotel nearby, then walked (maybe a few min?) to this hotel. If you ask for assistance at the limousine bus counter at the airport they are very helpful.

We only stayed here for two nights before he headed to Osaka. The hotel has a great location. Close to the train station (Chiyoda Line) and lots of restaurants within 5 minutes. Rappongi was also a short walk. The staff was wonderful...very friendly and helpful. The room was a bit small but I'm told it's good sized for Tokyo. The closet was small but at least it had a closet. The price was good.The room came with a "Handy"..a cellphone that had google maps programmed into it. You can use it to make free international phone calls. I would not hesitate to stay here again.

The good news--hotel is immaculate, good central location, comfortable beds, very helpful staff and a modern room with all the bathroom amenities that we wish we had at home. The only drawback is that the room is small and there are no drawers to put your clothing in. Bags are all over the floor. Thus with two people sharing the room in a large bed that is less than convenient. That is why we gave the hotel 4 stars instead of five. We took the breakfast plan. The attached restaurant serves a fine breakfast and one person had dinner there and enjoyed the food.

This hotel was great for us as a family. We had a twin room which was just enough for myself, husband and our 2 young children. The rooms are not big but for Tokyo and the price, it’s very reasonable. The hotel feels very new and clean and there is even a robot to greet you in the foyer! There are laundry facilities (washers and dryers) on the 12th floor with a vending machine to purchase washing power (50Yen each). This was fantastic to have in the building when traveling with kids! The location was quiet yet only a short walk from Akasaka subway station. There is a seven-eleven on the ground floor of the hotel which was very handy, and there was also a Lawson store over the road where we had breakfast everyday (sandwiches, yogurt, coffee etc). There are plenty of places to eat closer to the subway station and a Tulley Coffee place if you want something more substantial for breakfast. We didn’t try the hotel breakfast. The staff were helpful but English is not widely spoken in Japan so it’s useful to learn a few words. I must mention the free WiFi phone which is on every room and available to take out which is a great for getting around (especially in Tokyo!) and a fantastic perk from the hotel. They should advertise this more!! All in all a great stay and would definitely recommend!

The hotel is very good, with the rooms being a little larger than other hotels compared around the same price. The hotel staff is very friendly and provides good service and the hotel is 5 mins. away from one of the stops for the limousine bus (the hotel staff can also help order a seat on the limousine bus for returning to Narita airport). In the room you are also offered a free "handy", which you can bring along with you for having free 4g network while exploring the city. The restaurant is okay, however we mainly used the 7-eleven for purchasing our breakfast, since it was not too much for our taste.

The hotel is situated beautifully on the edge of Akasaka, a few minutes walk from tons of restaurants and a bustling city center (metro too). You're also about 1km from the infamous Ropponggi and a bit longer walk or easy taxi to Shibuya (Ometesando shopping backstreets), Tokyo Tower, Tsukiji Fish Market, and many more of Tokyo's finest attractions.All this, while being tucked away from too much noise that makes this hotel perfect for business travelers and families alike. Very good value, especially considering it's Tokyo. The rooms are a bit tight, but all the more reason to get out and explore. I did spend a number of hours working from the in-room desk, and it's absolutely manageable. Also there's a robot concierge. Truthfully, Pepper kinda freaked me out so I didn't look her in the eyes, but it's fun for the kids and pretty interesting.

Great stay here with the family. Very close to the metro and there are lots of places to eat or drink nearby. The room was nice size for Asia and very clean. Rooms cleaned everyday. I only wish they had connecting rooms because we had 2 rooms and it was difficult to manage with our small kids but otherwise no problems. We would stay here again no problem.

One of the nicest hotels we have stayed in for such a good price. The location is perfect - lots of walkable things to do and easy access to 7-11 for breakfast goods etc plus loads of great eating out spots and very close to 2 stations. The staff went out of their way to be so helpful and the room was spotlessly clean. We couldn’t have asked for anything more. The complimentary pyjamas, slippers and toiletries were fantastic - everything you could ever need and made for a very comfortable stay. Incredibly the room was equipped with a completely free mobile phone to take out and about into the city - with tips, maps etc - an absolute lifesaver. One of the best hotels we have stayed in. Pepper the concierge robot was great fun too! Thank you to all at Mystays premier Akasaka - would 100% recommend and stay again.

First time in a Mystays, and pretty impressed at the value offered. The room was small but not claustrophobically so. there were so many different amenities: fridge, water kettle, facial cleanser, toner and cream, a nice desk, USB by the bed (tho mine was broken) , etc. No closet, but rack and hangars on the wall. For this price point, its a good deal. This hotel differs from many in this price bracket by having a gym, and its free for all guests. the gym isn't that big, but it is enough for a workout. The only caution is that for foreigners trying to find the place and arriving by subway, you really need to know which exit to take and how to walk the small streets. Japanese streets are labelled clearly, even the main avenues, and many locals won't know the name of the road. The property is in the backstreets, and difficult to find, especially because it isn't tall, big or signposted... so beware. Once you do find it and get your bearings, the location is superb -- close to multiple subways, and walking distance to roppongi, and lots of conveniences and restaurants in the surrounding area.

I stayed here from 11-16 of February for business and I must say it is so so.The room is indeed very small and has only a coat rack to hang some clothes. Lucky I was alone otherwise it would not fit.The cushions are a bit smelly but the rest of the room is clean!The breakfast is not really Western. Only normal coffee, no cappuccino or something. Non eggs to order, only some scrambled eggs that are very soft (wet).For the high hotel prices in tokyo it was ok but don’t expect to much of it.

I made to this hotel walking from the nearby tube station on a heavily rainy afternoon. Once at the reception they saw I was drenched and politely I was offered a clean towel to dry my hair/face/jackets .... The check-in was easy the receptionists who spoke a very good english, she also booked me the taxi for the following morning.The room are standard for Tokyo, compact but clean, quiet and comfortable. I truly enjoyed it.

Hotel was closed to Metro station , there was a convenient store on the under ground floor ( in the same building) , room was not so small compared to other hotel in Tokyo but it was still relative small if compared to hotels in other country . Room was cleaned . Vast breakfast selection.

Pleasant stay and first time in the Akasaka area. Hotel is conveniently located with a great deal of privacy and quiet neighborhood. But it is only two blocks from the Akasaka Station, 1 km walk to Roppongi and Tokyo Midtown. Convenient coffee shops like Tullys nearby with a 7-Eleven at the ground floor of the hotel. Rooms are efficient and small but adequate for 1-2 people.

You can go walking by the metro station but is not so comfortable the street to walk with the suitcases The room is small but comfortable And has a bathtub The breakfast it’s ok not something out of this worldYou can go walking to akasaka district where you can find millions of restaurants

The other reviews are accurate in that the standard rooms are small but functional. I have seen smaller in NYC and Brussels. There is no closet but there is a place to hang up clothes. The room is big enough for a chair and desk, as well as a more lounge like chair too. The wifi works really well. The staff is a bit odd about being a stickler for time in a business hotel but maybe this is a Japanese culture thing? Not sure. Clean, neat, new, non-smoking, good breakfast, quiet, affordable, and just a few blocks from Akasaka Station. Does not have late night restaurant service or room service which is also a problem for business travelers working long hours.

Check in was easy. Changed to a bigger room for 2 people. The standard rooms are closets (which do not have a closet) which can be OK for single business traveler. Akasaka is a great neighborhood. Rooms were clean and unlike many Tokyo hotels the Non-Smoking rooms happily did smell smoke free. Breakfast was better than most similar business hotels (Ville Fontaine etc.). Because building was new fixtures and furniture nice an modern including the always fun Toto watersports toilets.Connected to 7-eleven so easy to stock fridge.I'll likely stay here again when the price is right... it can fluctuate from good deal to not so great when prices climb.

For a few days, this was very good. Close to business locations and subway. Rooms were clean and had right technology. Staff were friendly and the ambiance was quiet and relaxing. Price was super reasonable. If I get back, I will stay here again!

Summary: Great value, very comfortable stay, though the location was less convenient than other places we stayed on this trip.Pros - Excellent services and amenities, yet still very livable (microwaves, chopsticks, vending machines available on multiple floors; a couple of comfortable lounges with relevant reading material available) - Compact yet not cramped, no trouble stowing luggage for two in our room (one double bed) - Nice toiletries (e.g., toner and facial cleanser for ladies, shaving cream etc for men) - Excellent toilet and bathroom facilities (relatively Western style bathroom) - Well maintained and very clean - 7-Eleven downstairs and a pharmacy down the street - Firm and supportive pillows (contoured foam) and mattress - Windows open!Cons - Located in a quieter neighbourhood with fewer businesses; not particularly convenient to busiest centres of Tokyo (e.g. Roppongi, Shibuya, Shinjuku, Ueno)

The hotel is just 5-minute walk from Akasaka station and there are a good amount of restaurants and supermarkets nearby. The hotel is connected with a big 7-11 convenient store and there is no issue if you need any necessities. The hotel overall looks new and clean. The room is well appointed and I especially appreciate that they provide the mobile device cable. The flip side of this hotel is that the washroom is a bit smelly (I guess that's the odour from the sewage) and I need to use the air refresher quite often. Commute to/from airport is another issue. Overall speaking, the hotel is good value for money.

I've stayed at this hotel twice now and I will definitely use It again. The rooms are on the small side as Is the norm for Tokyo. However, they are clean and modern as the hotel was only built a year or so ago. It has laundry facilities and an Ice machine for your drinks needs. As to be expected with Japan there are 24 hour convenience stores very close by. Akasaka Is a great choice to stay when visiting Tokyo, The area Is more business orientated than tourist but It has enough places to eat and drink. Its also Ideal for accessing Shibuya and the surrounding areas If you are looking for that busy, shopping/tourist vibe. Definitely consider this hotel If It suits your Itinery.

This hotel is in a great location. Close to Akasaka station. Lots of restaurants 5 minute walk away. 35 mins walk to Shibuya. The hotel is modern, very clean, and the bed was very comfortable. Good size bathroom, safe and fridge in room, as well as multi charging adapter. The staff were very helpful and polite, and the robot concierge entertaining. The room was average size for Japan, but quite comfortable for 2 adults and all 2 big backpacks. We would definitely recommend this hotel.

this was the first hotel we stayed at on our trip round japan!the hotel is out of the centre and is based in a quite area, very modern and clean.the lobby is amazing and comes with its own robot.the staff were amazing too they allowed us to check in early (jetlag) and were just so helpful.the room was amazing too, small so much space at the same time. clean and comfortable and the bath is the best to soak in... :)all together a great hotel to stay at.
user_name:
Paul S
King's Lynn, United Kingdom

review_body: I stayed 5 nights in a superior room (616). Pro’s: - comfortable bed and super quiet.- bathroom with good water pressure and good toiletries.- price included breakfast which was handy although I thought the breakfast was ok but not great. - the hotel is in a great area.- good value for money.Con’s:- room was compact. If you are a party of 2 with luggage there wouldn’t be enough room. - pillows were too hard and small.- there was no card in the room so I could make known if I wanted my towels or bedding changed. One morning I asked one of the cleaners not to change the towels and that resulted in my room not being cleaned at all. - some staff members speak very little English.

The hotel is centrally located and is only a couple of metro stops from Ginza and Shibuya. It is only minutes away from Akasaka--you will need to take exit 5b, walk up a small flight of steps. At the top, turn right--you know you are heading in the right direction when you pass a pharmacy and are walking uphill. The reception staff are extremely helpful and allowed me to check in early without any fuss. There is a 7-11 in the basement, which serves snacks and hot food--they even offer to heat up your food purchases for you, but there are vending machines and microwaves in the hotel itself. There are also washing machines, but you will need to ask for an iron and board from the front desk. The rooms are on the small side but this is Tokyo! That said, the public spaces are great with a small on-site gym, fairly large restaurant (where breakfast is served), lounge area with outside space as well. The bonuses for me and why I chose this hotel are: brilliant wifi, English speaking TV channels (Japan tends to dumb western news channels), extensive breakfast spread that pander to Asian and Western cuisines, centrally located, and a good size lounge to work in. This hotel delivered on all these fronts. I would definitely stay at this hotel again on my next visit.

For such a small room it is incredibly well designed. We opted for the Queen bed as our days of sleeping on a double are long over. The location is great some 5 minute walk from hundreds of restaurants and bars. Also very close to two subways. Only negative thing I can say is that the pillows they have were a little firm for my liking.

This is a nice new hotel which is easy to get to. It is in a nice quiet area and still within a 10-15 minute walk to many restaurants and an active night life, However, it is off the main subway lines. Staff a good. English is not expansive and lead to a couple of minor misunderstandings - but all good. The room was nice and clean. It was quite small (as are most hotel rooms in Japan). I would definitely stay at HOTEL MYSTAYS PREMIER Akasaka again.

Overall, the 3 night stay in this hotel was very good. Main points:- very clean room and bathroom- breakfast was OK with good selection of Western and Japanese food- 7/11 convenient store attached to hotel- 2 subway lines within 5 and 7 minute walk- hotel was in a rather quiet but nice area (which is nice after a day of Tokyo craziness)- negative point is that you really need to walk 15-20 minutes to Roppongi (nightlife, shopping etc)- negative also that we arrived at 2:40pm but were told, check in is only at 3pm....so we had to sit in the lobby for 20 minutes....

We had 5 nights in this hotel.I must say, that I had never seen such a gap between the mark level and the reality ! Please hear this.A room called superior double room.1- has no closet to arrange clothAt a l l ! 2- more than this, the room is so tiny, that you have no accses to one side of the bedIn other city it can't consider even as a simple single room ! I really can't understand the high level that tourist gave to this fake hotelAnother issue is that they charge you in reception the full amount of staying when checking. May be they know why ?!....... (to prevent tourist to skip?.....) I would never recommend this hotel to anybody.And please don't tell me it's Japanese style hotel......If you are giving a description of a room, better provide the elements which match it.

This was a fabulous place to stay in Tokyo for those who like a quiet stay, yet don't want to be too far from the action. A short walk from the Chiyoda Metro Line which connects you to anywhere you'd want to go in the city, this nearly new hotel is a quiet oasis. Rooms are 'Japanese Size' of course, but very efficiently setup, modern and near silent to outside or room neighbour noise due to excellent construction. The bed is comfortable, and there are a good assortment of pillows available. They also provide any toiletry you need - including tooth brushes with toothpaste, and a variety of cremes. The shower is silky smooth. I also found this hotel to be excellent value, and the staff most helpful. Another nice touch is the lobby area - a beautiful front door, and water feature inside. Akasaka is also a reasonable walk to the Imperial Palace or Tokyo Midtown area, and has a number of great restaurants and places to shop. I would definitely consider staying here again when in Tokyo.

Our first time in Japan and son pleased that we chose this hotel for our stay in Tokyo. Central location , about 5mins walk from Metro. A choice of restaurants and bars alo in close proximity. Although the room was small (appears to be the standard in Jaan), it was well furnished and equipped with all conveniences. For anything that you may have forgot, ther is a 7/11 store in the basement of the hotel. All staff spoke English and service was polite and efficient. Breakfast is a mx between Japanese and buffet, something for everyone.

A very good tourist hotel, larger rooms than a typical business mans hotel, English speaking receptionist and a very handy 7-11 close by, good room amenities all the staff are very friendly and helpful. easy assess to the underground network and the area is saturated with excellent restraints.

It was the second time in Tokyo and in the Akasaka area. We picked the hotel for being close to the station about 5 minutes on foot. We had a fantastic 10 day-trip! Tokyo is amazing. The hotel is excellent, the front desk staff was polite and friendly, great team. Will definitely come back and recommend to family and friends!

We stayed at this hotel for four nights in August. It's in a lovely position only a five minute walk max from Akasaka station. The staff are extremely helpful and friendly. The rooms are modern and clean. Room size is small which is to be expected in Japan. We found the double bed to be a bit bigger than other bed sizes at other Japanese hotels we stayed at on this trip. We found the beds and pillows to be really comfortable. There is a 7-11 convenience store right under the hotel. It's also very close to ANA intercontinental hotel at Akasaka which is a main pickup spot for the Airport limousine bus. Overall we wouldn't hesitate to recommend this hotel to friends or family visiting Tokyo and will certainly be back to stay.

My fiancé and I had a great 4 night stay here. We came in from Narita Airport and we were easily able to take the train to the stop nearest here and walk just under 5 minutes! It's a great location with the train stop being just down the road. 5 minute ride to Tokyo Station and Shibuya. We loved the hotel itself too. There's a resturaunt inside, a 7/11 right underneath, and many resturaunts within walking distance. Our room was always clean and filled with many amenities. The hotel staff was very kind, even with our complete lack of Japanese. A great value! Overall made for an amazing stay in Tokyo!

1. Very good location , in central tokyo.2. Very clean , nicely maintained rooms.3. Rooms a bit small in size for a family stay.4. Breakfast good at the lobby level restaurant but choices for lunch and Dinner very limited.5. Staff at the reception very courteous and helping .6. Very well located near shopping Markets, Restaurants including Indian restaurants .7 . Convenience store 7 -11 right below the hotel. Very useful.

Typically small Tokyo room, but very neat and modern. Staff were all very helpful, even getting us a taxi for a 5 minute ride as we didn't want to walk in the rain! Location is up a small hill but nice enough, in an area with quite a few love hotels. Train station is only a 10 minute walk, and the Narita Airport limousine bus drops you at the ANA intercontinental which is a 5-10 minute walk from the hotel, and can pick you up again from there as well, so no issues with getting there from the airport. Overall a good stay!

A great find. Stayed in few mystays hotels in past but first time here. Step up from the others in great location near akasaka station. From here you can reach everywhere in reasonable time and it's on a nice residential patch away from all the noise. Would definitely go again and as a bonus it's rooms although small we're very well priced

Stayed there for a week, on business trip.Rooms of decent size for Tokyo standard, good bathroom.Small gym, but a lounge & terrace to get some work done with lot of natural light.7/11 downstairs.Surrounding streets are full of bars & restaurant, perfect to unwind after a long day.Breakfast was alright for westerners.

It is a reasonable place to stay for a very brief period mainly because the building is new and the location is good. Service is surprisingly poor for Japan. With badly cleaned rooms, no drinking water offered, a first for me in 30 years Japan, wrong transport information costing me time and money, no luggage keep unless you pay, cleaning staff messing up my luggage, really an unpleasant surprise. Breakfast really bad, although nice setting, but poor, very poor quality food for Japan. It could be good but it is not. A pity

First hotel for my first trip to Japan. So some kind of introduction to me for hotel standards in Japan. Hotel is a 5 minute walk from Akasaka metro station and a 10 minute walk from Tameike-Sanno metro station. Hotel was easy to find and looked brand new. Reception employees at welcoming are very nice and speak enough English to understand. We requested a upper level room. We were there at 1 pm and we needed to wait for another two hours to wait for a room and for the "official" check-in time. After our 15 hour trip, all we wanted to do actually was taking a shower and a short nap. After 15 minutes I couldn't take it anymore because I was already starting falling asleep in the lobby. So went to the reception and asked if we could go to our room earlier. Friendly lady said "yes, but it won't be at the upper floor because the one is finished at 3 pm.". So she wanted to grant our request which we initially made at the time of the booking. I thought it was really kind to keep in mind our request but room at one of the top floors was fine by me. So I kindly accepted a room on the 15th floor (out of 16). Room is small but after traveling Japan for two weeks I consider it acceptable and good size actually. With two suitcases it is pretty crowded. Very clean and comfortable. Bathroom was big enough and one of the cleanest I ever had. Heated toilet seat. All the things you need are there. Soundproof rooms. No sound from hallway or other rooms. Beds are very good and not to small for a tall European like me. Cleaning ladies are very quiet as well in the morning and work very hard. On the floor below reception there is a 7/11 and you can enter it directly from the hotel. On reception floor is also a very good restaurant with good food. Across the street you have I little nice tapas place. The location of the hotel is good but keep in mind you are not on the Yamanote Line (Loop). Roppongi is around the corner. Late at night there are not a lot of restaurants open in the neighborhood. Very good hotel overall and would stay again because of the quiet area.

A great place to stay. Modern, almost new hotel. Good breakfast, excellent showers, comfortable bed, efficient housekeeping, good air conditioning. Everything you'd want for a business or leisure stay. Close to good local restaurants.

We ended up here after a horrid Airbnb experience and this became our sanctuary for the weekend. We had just relocated to Tokyo and were staying in Airbnbs before moving into a permanent place. After a terrible one night stay at a place that reeked of mildew and covered in black mold, we escaped to here for the weekend. We arrived early and left our 8 big bags with the hotel crew. Instead of giving us weird or dirty looks, they happily helped us store the luggage in the backroom. When we checked-in in the afternoon, our bags were already upstairs in our room. The room was a little small for a family of 4 but it was clean and comfortable. We desperately needed a clean and fresh place after the botched airbnb stay and this was the perfect hotel to detox. The staff was friendly, responsive, and respectful, we really had nothing but gratitude for their services. Akasaka itself was ok, tons of great restaurants and ample shopping, it was a nice departure from residential neighborhoods that we stayed prior. This place was great, we would stay there again in a heartbeat, highly recommend it for those who are looking for comfort, convenience, and good services.

Spent a weekend in the area, and booked this hotel in a superior double room.The hotel is very new, and the rooms are very clean.Many will say that room is small, but i found it a little bit bigger than the japanese standards. Very nice bathroom with a big bathtub. Free wi-fi works good and there are smoker rooms.I think it is one of the best price/value relationship i have found around. Akasaka is a nice neighbourhood with lots of restaurants, izakaya, etc... and walking distance to Roppongi in case somebody is looking for some party night ;)

We stayed here for four nights and what we liked about the hotel were: good location (a 5 minute walk from Akasaka Station, a convenience store on the basement floor of the hotel in case you get the late night munchies), clean rooms (albeit a bit tiny for the two of us but Japanese hotel rooms are known to be on the smaller side). We arrived on a rainy night and upon arrival, the staff quickly handed us towels to dry ourselves and our luggage, and that gesture was very much appreciated. I would stay here again.

Very convenient for where we wanted to be, around Akasaka, (to be at a wedding party), and then the shops, nightlife, restaurants, historical shrines, and close easy tube rides, to other parts of Tokyo. Hotel only opened last year, staff friendly, clean & modern rooms, although fairly small, which after 7 days felt a bit cramped, but nice bathroom.

Perfect location, near subway and Roppongi. Rooms spacious enougha nd very clean . Very good bed, extremly courtesy staffOnly average will be on the food and beverage side. Missing at least a bar for drinks when meeting people

The Mystays Akasaka has a nice location about a 3-4 min walk away from the Asakasa stop of the Tokyo metro, although a bit hard to find at first, and the rooms are teeny tiny but spotlessly clean and recently updated. The bathroom is nice and has a tub and shower, and they provide nice toiletries and bath amenities; the room has an air conditioner, a hot water kettle, and a desk/chair area. They were kind enough to accept and store our luggage several hours before check-in time, while we explored Tokyo. The neighborhood is fairly quiet - there's a 7-11 store downstairs, a hotel restaurant, and more restaurants/grocery stores nearby.

Stayed there with my wife for 3 nights after we decided to move out of our AirBNB room and just let our kids use it. Since it was peak season, (especially it being the Sakura blooming season) Hotel Mystays was the only one that still had available rooms at reasonable rates. We were also convinced because of the good ratings the hotel received from other reviewers. The location is near the Akasaka station and was within reasonable distance from Tokyo's main attractions, such as Shibuya crossing, Harajuku, Ginza shopping, etc. Check in was a breeze and the breakfast buffet was in my opinion, acceptable. They had the usual continental and japanese fare but don't expect lots of choices. The only thing that disappointed us was that since we were a couple, we found the room very small, even smaller than Japan standards (This is our 4th trip to Tokyo). The bathroom door opened outwards so if you had the luggage in the hallway, you'll have to move it to be able to enter. The bed though was comfy and the linens were fresh. I would say that the overall experience was satisfactory and we would be willing to stay in this hotel again in the future but book a bigger room instead of the standard deluxe.

Chose this hotel because it's modern and clean and a short metro ride away from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo-Staff were excellent and professional and always helpful (esp considering we don't speak Japanese)The room was clean and maintained ell during our 5 night stay- they have a luggage service which transports your luggage to your next destination so definitely worth the AUD $18 we spent to ship our big suitcase to our next destination.One tip- use the tameike sanno station which is a few minutes walk from the Main Street (across the road from Starbucks) it will shorten your walk when compared with taking the underground walkway which eventually gets you to the same place! RoomWas a little on the small side ( we had a queen room) and the other other issue was the pillow (they give you two, one is the memory foam which is nottoe everyone and the other pillow is about2/3'of the size of a normal pillow (strange but it is what it is)All in all I would stay here again!!!

Professional staff, well-appointed room and a nice property. Breakfast has quite an extensive variety too (Japanese style). Location wise, it is within 5 mins walk to the nearest train station, and within walkable distance to the Akasaka restaurant area. In fact, there are also many food choices around the hotel area.Wifi connection very stable too, and the hotel is not located on a busy street, so very quiet.The only issue I would have is probably the memory foam pillow, that I had commented in my stay with another property under the same chain.Would love to be back at this property again though!

We really enjoyed our stay at Hotel Mystays Premier Akasaka. The staff was very helpful and spoke good english. They were very willing to help us with directions on how to get around. It is a quiet neighbourhood for those who don't want to go through crowds to your place of rest. I wouldn't say it is an immediate walking distance to many attractions but it is a 3 minute walk to the closest subway station. The room is very clean, well kept and new. The rooms are small but this is what you get in Tokyo. It is very convenient that there is a 24 hour 7-11 in the building next door.

The hotel is a 7min walk to a few good eateries, movie theater and an underground rail system located in Tokyo Midtown, the rooms are clean, compact and suits more a... business, get a quiet nap and head out the next day, kind of vibe, the beds aren't the most comfortable, more one the firm side, but it will do. The staff is very respectful and helpful, the gym is small, the amenities provided and the sitting area on the 3rd floor is nice. Overall a pleasant stay.

Small room with lots of stuff, which make it hard to move around. Expensive without breakfast. A bit far from bus and metro and hard to carry many lauggages. Positive with a 7/11 store downstair. Nice staff with good English knowlege. Very clean.

Newer hotel in a very pleasant area of Tokyo. Small room but clean and functional. Staff were friendly and spoke good English. Great location, close to the metro and nice restaurants. Would highly recommend it!

Chose this hotel for a business trip thanks to all the positive reviews here. The hotel is reasonably priced and good size for Tokyo at this price range. It is surprisingly convenient with the subway and a major food area only 5 mins away. There's also a 7 Eleven right at the basement of the hotel. If you're here for shopping, I'd choose somewhere closer to Ginza/Shibuya/Shinjuku. Otherwise I'd highly recommend this one!

This new and modern hotel is conveniently located at 5 minutes on foot from the Akasaka subway station, which means you can quickly reach interesting Tokyo locations such as Shibuya. The room was very clean and silent (although a little on the small side, as usual in Tokyo). TV, fridge, cosmetics, usual Japanese robes and slippers are all provided - there's even a more extensive choice of complimentary Shiseido beauty products by the front desk. The service was courteous and efficient but could be more flexible (we arrived jetlagged after 12 PM and were asked to wait until 3 PM for the room to become available). Apart from that the hotel is excellent, considering the price and the location. Lots of good restaurants and convenience stores nearby, even a love hotel (interestingly called Chantilly).

Spent 5 days at Mystays and found it to be a very pleasant place. The hotel has been recently remodeled and it still has that new feel. Stayed on the 11th floor and had some views of the skyline. The room was small but it was more efficiently layed out than the last time we stayed in Tokyo. We ate at the restaurant one night and had a very good meal at a reasonable price. We used the gym once and found it to be clean and well equipped for a small hotel. There is lots places to eat near by especially near Akasaka Station which is about a 5 minute walk. I would highly recommend Mystays if staying the area.

I get to stay in Tokyo a number of times and with my usual hotel being unavailable and wanting to stay close to my office, I was given this as a recommendation. This is a new hotel that opened in early 2016 and it very well located with bars and resturants a short walk away, plus also close to the subway. The rooms are compact but functional, and everything is absolutlely spotless. The room had a humidifer plus air conditioning which performed very well. Internet connection (wi-fi) was outstanding and the large screen TV offered large selection of channels and pay for movies. Although only a single free Englsh speaking news channel. Bathroom was usual Japanese standard and in my room had a shower in the bath rather than seperate. A very good selection of toiletries were provided that were topped up each day, and although I do not usually use any of these hotel items, these were so good I did not use any of my own. Pyjamas and slippers were provided in the room as well. Tea making facilities were also in the room, but disappointingly no sachets of coffee. The bed was a double and was comfortable, but i have never had such a hard pillow, zero bend, zero plump, and I had to check that this was not a breeze block wrapped in a pillow case... :-) Other available pillows were fine as were the cushions. The only other negative point, was there is no drawers or storage space for clothes, so still had to live out of a suitcase whilst staying here. There is a small hanging area for clothes with space for 6 hangers, but nothing else. Don't do breakfast, so can't comment on the food. Would certainly return as the value, location, cleanliness and service offered are superb.

New, modern, comfy and pretty decent size rooms per Japan's standard. Lot of good restaurants / cafes / bars in the area and walking distance to train station.Overall enjoyed our stay here and will recommend it to friends.

This Akasaka branch of the MyStays chain is about a year old, and the interior is still spotless. I stayed in a double room which was compact, but still had room for a chair and coffee table as well as the built in desk and chair. Furnishings are light and bright and the full-size Japanese bath is a bonus.This is a no-frills business hotel, with the standard complimentary pyjamas and bathroom amenities. It has its own cafe serving a fairly ordinary breakfast and dinner, but the 7-Eleven on the ground floor and the supermarket at Akasaka subway station (5 mins walk to the end of the street) mean that you can easily self-cater. The room has a small refrigerator and kettle.What it lacks in charm it makes up for in location (5 mins to Akasaka shops and restaurants) and cost performance - very reasonable rate for a Tokyo hotel.Not all taxi drivers will find it easily, so take the little map on the card at reception or get them to plug the address into their GPS.

Good value for money considering Tokyo prices.Well located AKASAKA metro station near by.Reception staff very polite .Breakfast ok and fast . The restaurant is pleasant for dinning also.Rooms small ( Tokyo ) but have all amenities needed.Overall a pleasant stay and would go back again

Our 1st time to Tokyo, we travel in a group and hotel was booked by organizers. it was a very good experience. Location is very good, within walking distance you find many restaurants, wine bars, jazz club (2), convenient store, public transportation. I noticed that many business visitors stay there so its probably also convenience to this kind of visitors. those who The room was nice, not huge but well organized. They have a small table and 2 chairs in front of the bed which is useless and occupied the space in front of the bad. We just concentrate them in one corner so we have good space. I strongly recommend the management to remove them from the room. All other room enmities were very good, efficient. Breakfast was good with nice variety of western and Japanese dishes. Staff was very helpful kind and knowledgeable. Taking into consideration that this is a new hotel every thing was shining and efficient (but this is Japan so I'm convinced it will be the same for years). Very good experience. ,

I have stayed in Tokyo dozens of times and in a variety of locations. Akasaka is my favourite area. Close and convenient to everything. This hotel appears to be brand new and is a 5-minute walk to Akasaka or Tameike sanno stations.Even though I asked for a higher floor, due to my late check-in, I was given a room on the 2nd floor.The room was generally clean and modern, but extremely tiny even by Tokyo standards. There is no room to store your luggage.The bed is super comfortable and the room quiet - 2 features absolutely crucial to me. Bathroom and shower facilities were excellent.So, overall, I would recommend this hotel for anyone seeking a great location and good night's sleep. Just don't expect to hang out in your room all day to spread your wings...

Firstly, don't get me wrong, the hotel installations are fine although rooms are smaller than I hoped for. The service has a lot of gaps. Let me start from the beginning, looks like staff hasn't been fully trained and a couple of times I called the front asking for something and I was told someone will call me back but never got that call. I requested a massage before noon but they didn't know anything about that so they also tell me I will be called back and then the masseuse showed up at my door. I asked him if they didn't have a room for that but he said he doesn't know and that on the bed would be ok, massage was good but don't think my room was the best location. Didn't have any cash and they don't work with credit so I had to go down to an ATM to get money for the guy that was waiting for me at the lobby.I also ask for laundry in the afternoon right after I arrived, would be ready by 18pm next day, which is fine but no one would come pick it up and I had to go down to the lobby to get the laundry bags go to my room, do down to front and they started taking my clothes out right there to count them and was asked to pay in advance, no charging to the room was allowed. Breakfast next day, I came down 9:30, 30 minutes before finish, I couldn't charge it to the room again, 5 minutes later they started rushing through the buffet picking things up and by 10:00 everything was gone although I was told by the cashier when I paid in advance that breakfast was until 10:00. So disappointed that if I hadn't made a two day reservation that they charged me in advance I would have left. I asked if I could cancel but obviously NO was the answer. I'm still at the hotel but couldn't wait to write this review. The way this is going I don't even think there will be a follow up email or call from the hotel but let's see.To be continued...

If you are looking for a quiet stay after the hustle and bustle moments in busy Shibuya and Shinjuku, this is the place.Opened just a few months ago, the hotel is clean and nice with helpful front office staff who tried very hard to answer my questions in English.Less than 3 minutes walk to Akasaka station and 5 minutes to the bigger Akasaka-Mitsukae station, it is just a few train stops to the popular districts of Shinjuku and Shibuya.The subways are easy to use with very clear directions every few steps you take.The hotel has a lounge and gymnasium on the third floor. The hotel is very strict with extended check out time. Each extra hour cost 2,000 yen. They don't even allow the use of the lounge after check out. And they do not offer good maps of the city and the subway stations which other hotels do. I suppose it is because of their positioning as a business hotel as I see it catering more to the business travellers. Rooms are clean because it is still new.Nearby restaurants and shops are not as aplenty as other areas and you will need to walk about 5 minutes to the area around Akasaka-Mitsukae station to look for more lively happenings.

The hotel is open for only a few months and is like new when I stayed. I come because of website laurels and it lives up to much of it. Yes, the room is small but comfortable and well-equipped with toiletries, hair-dryer, quality linen, comfortably pyjama, fridge, large TV, and there is even a microwave on each floor in the ice room. Lobby is 5-star like and staff are good and they do speak English adequately (rare for budget hotels in Tokyo). All good except one thing: the location. It is in a dark area of Akasaka, some 8 minutes of uphill walk and difficult to locate (not 4 minutes) from the metro station Akasaka, which itself is not very good being on the Chiyoda line that doesn't go to places that I want (or for most visitors). Still good, given this location (perhaps thus the price).

This hotel was just recently built and I was surprised at how clean and comfortable it is for the price. Was around 90 dollars a night and stayed for business for two weeks.. there is a nice terrace, gym, and lounge space on the third floor. Also they give you good amenities where you can take as many as you need on the third floor which is convenient. Spacious bath tub as well. The best part of the stay were the people! They are very professional kind and thoughtful I think it had a service of a five star hotel! I'd def recommend anyone who is looking for a cheaper alternative in the middle of the city. Walking distance to Roppongi and all the great restos in Akasaka which is the best place to stay for it's convenience in Tokyo. There is a bus that leaves from ana intercontinental hotel to narita airport too which is only a five min walk

I loved this place. It's modern and clean. The staff were very nice and efficient. The rooms are small but very practical and comfortable. Breakfast buffet was great. 7/11 downstairs is very convenient for a late night night bottle of water.I would definitively stay there again.

I used this hotel to stay another night in Tokyo after moving out of my house. I love how clean it is, and the location. However the room was tiny. And you have to pass the casual hotel for couples to sleep together (so called ”love hotel”), which wasn't a great feeling. It's indeed right in town but I felt like it didn't provide regular three star city hotel service. Best for budget business traveler and can't be a good fit for budget tourists.

We have been there on May 2008 for 2 weeks. Very nice stay. Great located, near by Ropponghi /just about 10 mins to walk/, Ceasar¨s palace, TBC building, close to subway station. Very simple, but nice, clean, quiet and comfortable rooms with aircon. Bathrooms are really tiny, but it is a Japanies style of living and a man can get used on it very fast. There is 7th Eleven shop near by to buy whatever a man need. A public laundry is in. And the price is absolutely great for such a location. I would choose definitely this accomodation next time in Tokio. For everyone who is looking for Akasaka Weekly Mansion - this is it :).
